article:
An 'Induction' in a play is an explanatory scene or other intrusion that stands
outside and apart from the main action with the intent to comment on it,
moralize about it or in the case of dumb show to summarize the plot or
underscore what is afoot. Inductions are a common feature of plays written and
performed in the Renaissance period, including those of Shakespeare. Example of
inductions in Shakespeare are the dumb show in [[Hamlet]] and the address to the
audience by Puck in [[A Midsummer Night's Dream]]. Another example, in [[The
Spanish Tragedy]] by Thomas Kyd, is the introduction to that play by the ghost
of Andrea who preps the audience by laying out the story to come. Likewise,
Shakespeare's [[The Taming of the Shrew]] opens with induction scenes which
involve characters watching the play proper.
